1. Report of Portfolio Committee on Human Settlements on oversight visit to the Western Cape, dated 14 April 2010
The Portfolio Committee on Human Settlements, having undertaken an oversight to the Western Cape from 31 January to 5 February 2010, reports as follows:
1. Background

The Constitution of the Republic of South Africa of 1996, as well as parliamentary rules, mandates parliamentary committees to exercise oversight over any executive organ of state that falls within their respective portfolios. The Committee undertook an oversight visit to the Western Cape to oversee the following:

. Implementation of a Comprehensive Integrated Human Settlements Strategy in the province. . Quality of housing units to ensure an alignment of allocated expenditure, as well as meeting service delivery targets set for 2008/09. . The plans, programmes and service delivery targets for 2009/10. . The number of informal settlements: the plans and progress in upgrading such settlements, including the Community Residential Units (CRUs). . The role of the public and private sectors in human settlements service delivery. . The co-ordination and management of the beneficiary list and the incorporation of backyard dwellers onto the provincial housing database. . The use of alternative technologies on projects. . Further issues on: o Reports on communities affected by disasters; delays in projects and plans and solutions; and progress and plans on the rectification programme; implementation of the Farm Workers Assistance Programme

The parliamentary delegation consisted of Ms BN Dambuza (leader of the delegation (ANC)); Mr MR Mdakane (ANC); Ms TMA Gasebonwe (ANC); Mr Matshoba (ANC); Ms NA Mnisi (ANC) ; Ms V Bam-Mugwanya; Mr AM Figlan (DA) ; Mr AC Steyn (DA) and Mr T Botha (COPE).

The delegation was also accompanied by officials from the National Department of Human Settlements, i.e. Ms J Bayat, Mr L Jolobe and Ms N Tembani. Provincial departmental officials included Ms J Samson, Mr R Smith, Mr V Tshose and Ms N Hadi. The Knysna Municipality was represented by the Executive Mayor, Ms E Bouw-Spies, Mr JB Douglas, (Municipal Manager); Ms L Waring and Mr D Kemetie. Parliamentary support staff included Ms K Pasiya (Committee Secretary) and Mr F Bulawa (Committee Assistant). 2. Overview of briefings and oversight activities
Sunday, 31 January 2010
2.1 Meeting in Knysna Municipal Offices

The provincial Department of Human Settlement's Chief Director, Planning and Development, Ms J Samson, welcomed the delegation. She tendered an apology on behalf of the MEC, Hon. B Madikizela, who was unable to meet with the delegation.
Opening remarks by Ms BN Dambuza: Overview and objective of oversight visit

Ms BN Dambuza thanked the Provincial Department, as well as all who attended the meeting. She indicated that whilst the apology from the MEC was both noted and accepted, it would have been empowering if the delegation was welcomed by the public representative. She, however, expressed her appreciation to the MEC for assistance provided to the Committee in order to undertake oversight in the province. She further indicated that an apology was also submitted by Mr M Dlabantu, Acting Director-General of the National Department of Human Settlements.
Ms Dambuza proceeded to indicate that the objectives of the oversight visit are in line with the parliamentary mandate:

. To oversee projects, and ascertain whether there was value for money in undertaking all projects. . To evaluate the impact of government programmes on the lives of the people In conclusion, Ms Dambuza stated that in 2004, the Department adopted a new strategy, called Breaking New Ground (BNG). This strategy promotes the establishment of integrated and sustainable human settlements. The aspect of housing was further highlighted in the 2009 State of the Nation Address. This focus was on reversing the trend of further exacerbating spatial marginalisation of the poor by achieving new modes of intergovernmental integration.
Presentation by Ms J Samson: Chief Director Planning Briefing on the provincial Strategic Plan
The presentation highlighted that the provincial department was:

. Accelerating the provision of housing opportunity, including the prioritisation of services-sites. The provincial Department would upscale the provision and implementation of service-sites and to reduce bulk infrastructure as a constraint to human settlement development. . Inculcating a sense of ownership and responsibility amongst housing beneficiaries, tenants and owners. The Department was planning to increase beneficiary involvement and educate owners, beneficiaries and tenants them on rights and responsibilities, as well as the development of housing opportunities. . Developing a standardised, transparent and fair policy processes for the selection of housing beneficiaries. . Optimising the use of resources and partnership to increase the density of new housing developments on well located land, and increasing private/public sector partnerships. . Introducing a coordinated approach to human settlements through effective Integrated Development Planning (IDP) or human settlements planning. The Department will assist potential municipalities to become accredited as housing developers. . Establishing a fully functional department capacitated to deliver services. Ms Samson also raised the following key issues:

. The Province has a housing demand database support programme. The aim is to support non-metro municipalities to strengthen housing demand data collection and management systems and practices. The database will be on a needs-based register, indicating an applicant's profile. . The Province will identify vulnerable informal and backyard settlements. Disaster, fire and floods would be the determiners of a risk management strategy. The Province has developed an informal settlement master plan, with clear plans for each identified informal settlement. . A database showing informal settlements, temporary settlements or relocation areas database will be collated. The Province would be able to accelerate in-site upgrading and develop recommendations to progressively provide all informal settlements with improved infrastructure and tenure. . The Department completed two sizeable projects under the rectification programme. Within the City of Cape Town, a total of 2 200 units were completed, while in George, approximately 400 units were phased within municipal housing allocations. . In the Western Cape, alternative technologies were used in the construction of the N2 Gateway project. The Danish Government donated R10 million for installation of solar water heaters, while thermally efficient material was utilised in some of the houses. ABSA bank administers a Show Village Competition which serves as an opportunity for showcasing various housing concepts. These were on display for evaluation by communities in Paarl. . With respect to performance on delivery targets, during the third quarter of 2009/10, the department managed to acquire and serviced 11 071 sites, and constructed 12 163 houses.

The table below provides an overview of provincial expenditure during the 2009/10 financial year: Table 1: Expenditure for 2009/10 |Provincial allocation 2009/10 |Expenditure |Balance | |Programme |Amount in rands | | | |IHHSD |1 234 088 000 |934 775 520 |299 312 480 | |N2 Funding |250 000 000 |79 083 768 |170 916 232 | |Other programs |97 337 000 |67 870 884 |29 466 116 | |Total |1 581 425 000 |1 081 730 172 |499 694 828 |

The provincial service delivery targets for all programmes for 2010/11 were to acquire approximately 18 156 serviced sites, to construct 15 457 houses and to construct 5 121 houses in other programmes.
Deliberations
Members of the delegation raised the following issues:

. The current status of the provincial housing database was queried, and whether there was a collaborative link between the three spheres of government? . The lack of capacity in municipalities, and whether how the Province provides assistance to the regional offices and regional team offices? The current situation with regard to the accreditation of municipalities was also questioned. . The installation of services in dense settlements. . The number of informal settlements. . Plans to assist farm worker and or farm dwellers, vulnerable groups and backyard dwellers. . The challenges posed by land shortages and whether the department had conducted a land audit. . Managing challenges related to the beneficiary list. . The status of in-situ upgrading of shacks.

In response, the provincial department indicated that the previous database did not include a link to the three spheres of government. Instead, only the national Department was able to access the database. At the time of the oversight, Knysna was the only region that implemented a sound database. Furthermore, the department indicated that accreditation was currently in process, and there was a need to capacitate municipalities. Level one and two accreditation would be finalised by the end of 2010, while level three accreditation would require approval from National Treasury. The Department acknowledged that the vision of the Housing 20/30 strategy aimed to assist municipalities that had capacity challenges, especially in rare skills.

The provincial Department indicated that there was a total of 715 informal settlements located across the province. The informal settlement upgrading process was prioritised through the provision of greenfield sites. The province was also using in-situ upgrading in the metro, where a total of 253 informal settlements had been upgraded. Across the province, there were about 550 informal settlements earmarked for in-situ upgrading.

Farm workers were assisted through programmes implemented by municipalities, although there was no specific programme dedicated only to farm dwellers. The province acknowledged that the issue of farm workers continued to be a challenge, and argued that it was challenging and expensive to maintain or provide houses on farms. The province was, however, collaborating with the Department of Agriculture and Land Affairs to address the challenges of evictions of farm workers by farm owners. However, the province proposed that this issue would require a national response, since the province experienced farm evictions on a daily basis.

It was indicated that the provincial Department of Human Settlements was in the process of developing a policy in relation to people with special needs, with assistance from provincial departments of Health and of Social Development. While houses were constructed for people with disabilities, the Association for the Blind registered objections to its specifications. The province was, however, in the process of improving this aspect of its housing programme.

The province indicated that it regarded backyard dwellings as part of informal settlements. In this regard, a 50 m serviced sites were made available to build 40 m2 houses. However, the unavailability of well- located land was a significant challenge and required further attention. It was revealed that the provincial Department did not have a programme in place to address the issue of accessing land. However, a land audit was conducted on public and private land during 2006. It was suggested that the Housing Development Agency (HDA) should assist in land-related challenges, especially in acquiring prime land.

The Mayor of Knysna, Ms Spies, informed the delegation that the area was further challenged by steep land, coupled with forestry villages that do not have access to basic services. For example, in Crystalfontein, forestry and Transnet land was very difficult to access, and the process took approximately three years to be finalised.

The national Department mentioned that it considered different alternative energy- providing and construction technologies, such as the N2 Gateway project, where the Danish government sponsored R10 million for the installation of solar water heaters. The ABSA 'show village competition' involved developers across the globe in order to showcase and explore creativity and innovation in housing construction, together with energy efficiency.

The sale of houses by beneficiaries was an obstacle to government in reaching its policy objectives. It was revealed that a study conducted showed that almost 50% of the beneficiaries were not staying their house in Du Noon. In George, about 90% of government-assisted houses were sold or illegally rented to foreign nationals, due to levels of poverty in the community. As such, it created a need to review relevant policies. While policy provisions made allowance for a minimum period of eight years before a beneficiary could sell a house, this had not been adhered to. The national department suggested the need for beneficiaries to be educated to perceive and use their houses as assets, while the issue of title deeds should be followed up. The national department specified that the backyard dwellers policy would be addressed at national level.
In conclusion, Ms Dambuza requested a report from the Knysna municipality on land-related challenges, especially in the forestry and Transnet areas.
Monday, 1 February 2010
2.2 Meeting at Plettenberg Bay municipal offices

The delegation was welcomed by the Mayor, Mr L Mvimbi. He informed the delegation that the municipality had a population of 7 000 people, 7 wards and 13 councillors. The municipality received a budget of R355 million for the 2009/10 financial year, of which R100 million had already been spent. The municipality had a housing backlog of approximately 1 200 units, while the municipality was faced with budgetary constraints. A total of five projects were implemented in the municipal area, ie:
. Bossiesgif. . Kwanokuthula. . Bitou Emergency Housing project Project (EHP). . Kranshoek phase 2. . Kurtland phase 2.
(a) Bossiesgif project

The project to build 1 300 units was approved in August 2005. Phase 1 consisted of 265 serviced sites. By the time of the visit, more than 90% of the top structure had already been completed. In phase 2, bulk infrastructure was towards the completion of 540 units by February 2010. The entire budget for the project amounted to R 42 2000 00.

The municipality encountered challenges with illegal occupants who forcefully occupied houses, and the municipality sought to obtain a court interdict for eviction. Another challenge relates to land that was very expensive for the purposes of either purchase or expropriation.
(b) Kwanokuthula project

The municipality received a conditional approval to build 2 000 units during 2008. The project was subsequently divided into four phases. The bulk infrastructure has been completed, and additional sites will be serviced by March 2010. Show houses were constructed. The closing date for submission of tenders in respect to the construction of top structures for 134 units in phase 1 was 1 February 2010. The municipality faced considerable pressure from the community to complete construction of the top structures. The municipality was, however, not in a position to complete this due to budgetary constraints, and indicated that it had already spent more than the funding allocated for the project.
(c) Bitou Emergency Housing Project (EHP)

The project was initiated in July 2008, after an assessment was completed on the houses damaged by storms in Green Valley and Kranshoek. The information was analysed and the cost estimates for the work was compiled. The project was valued at R16 million, and divided into six smaller projects to give opportunities to local contractors who upgraded at the lower end of the Construction Industry Development Board (CIDB) grading register;

. Project 1 and 2: The construction of aprons around the houses was complete. At the time of the visit, the V-drain was under construction. . Project 3: Houses in Kranshoek had been repaired, plastered and painted. . Project 4: In Green Valley, 13 out of 15 houses that were demolished had been rebuilt, and others houses repaired. . Project 5: Upgrading of infrastructure of the Kranshoek project was delayed until additional funds were approved. Excavation for storm water drainage pipelines were under construction. . Project 6: Upgrading of civil services in Green Valley was terminated due to non-performance by the contractor and re-awarded to Ukhana Projects. Excavations for the storm water draining were under construction.

Challenges encountered include that some of the houses were not registered, especially in Green Valley. Subsequently, additional resources were needed to ensure that unregistered houses were also repaired. Further, it was suggested that the capacity of local contractors required improvement.
(d) Kranshoek phase 2

Phase 1 of the project consisted of 400 units and had been completed. An application for 670 units was submitted to the province for approval. However, the application was rejected and returned to the municipality. The municipality budgeted for the installation of bulk infrastructure from its own funds for the 2009/10 capital budget. The application was for the construction of 235 units.

The Mayor informed the delegation that the eradication of the housing backlog in Bitou was one of the major challenges that faced the municipality. The eradication of informal settlements and backyard dwellers would also assist in eradicating the housing backlog. The Mayor indicated that the municipality would ensure that informal settlements were eradicated and that people would be housed in habitable conditions. As such, this commitment served as the rationale for the municipality's plea for the approval of applications for top structure where services had been installed.

The Mayor specified that the provincial allocations for housing delivery for the 2009/10 financial year was R11 million; the upgraded allocation for 2009/10 was R15 800 000 which brought the total for housing delivery to R26 800 000. The budget for the approved projects for 2009/10 was R30 821 192 of which R17 894 801 was not approved
2.3 Site visits
2.3.1 Bossiesgif

It was pointed out that some beneficiaries started to move into their new houses during May 2009. The size of each house was 40 m. It was observed that the houses were of good quality, and had ventilation, a toilet and a shower. Retaining walls were built as part of the subsidy. Some sites were not yet allocated. However, the sites for schools and other amenities were identified. The delegation discussed the issue of densification with communities, who in turn agreed to relocate when advised to.
2.3.2 Kwanokuthula 5 and 6

With the approval of the National Home Builders Registration Council (NHBRC), a number of innovative show houses were built in Kwanokuthula. The delegation observed that people were temporarily occupying show houses, due to their homes that have been damaged by natural disasters.
2.3.3 Flenters in Knysna

The project was a managed People's Housing Process (PHP) where 790 houses were built as an in-situ upgrading. A tender was awarded to 12 emerging contractors for different phases. Roofs were tiled. The project was labour intensive with very high technical specifications. The project faced challenges related to topographical conditions.
2.4 Briefing by the Deputy Mayor of Knysna

The Deputy Mayor indicated that the municipality had a population of 68 000. The housing backlog on the waiting list constituted 8 000 beneficiaries. Some of the pre-1994 houses transferred to beneficiaries were damaged, and additional funding to rectify these houses was pending approval. There were no blocked projects in the area, and the NHBRC was involved in most of the projects. Social housing had a challenge of affordability, and the municipality was considering Community Residential Units (CRUs) in this regard. The waiting list, funding and the land issue were some of the challenges faced by the municipality.
The Deputy Mayor requested the delegation's assistance with the following challenges faced by the municipality:

. Upgrading of backyard dwellings in Hornlee. . Rectification of pre-1994 houses. . Additional funding required. . Acquisition of land. . Security of tenure. . Rural development. . Slow procurement processes.

The delegation asked whether the municipality received more funding towards the end of the financial year (fiscal dumping), and what were the plans of the municipality in dealing with backyard dwellers. In response, the Deputy Mayor indicated that the municipality experienced fiscal dumping from the province; however the municipality managed to utilize it effectively.
(a) Site visit to Pacaltzdorp

The project was approved in 2007. The Mayor informed the delegation that the MEC was going to turn the sod on that day to kick start the project. The delegation congratulated the beneficiaries and reminded them that home ownership was a basic right. Beneficiaries were urged not to sell their houses, and to pay for basic services.

The environment impact assessment (EIA) process took over four years to be approved. The houses to be constructed will be 40 m, with a tiled roof and ceiling. However, the area experienced water-related challenges.
On turning the sod, the MEC thanked the parliamentary delegation, the Acting Mayor and officials representing both the national and provincial departments.

Ms Dambuza acknowledged the municipality for its coordination of the beneficiary list. She argued that delays in the EIAs, which hampered progress in most projects, were a critical issue. She further encouraged beneficiaries not to sell their houses, and the municipality in turn to educate beneficiaries to understand the cost associated with constructing houses.
The MEC then officially initiated a new project through the turning of the sod.
2.5 Complaints from the local councillors in Pacaltzdorp

The councillors complained that it was mostly coloured people who benefited from the Pacaltzdorp project. They further suggested that the list of beneficiaries was not co-ordinated. They argued that, there were only 35 beneficiaries from Thembalethu, and those 35 beneficiaries were not informed and not invited for the turning of the sod event. Ms Dambuza assured the councillors that the matter would be referred to the Minister and the Acting Mayor to be addressed, and thereafter to be reported on to the Committee. A special meeting would be arranged to address issues raised by the councillors.
2.6 Meeting at Great Brak Municipal Offices

The delegation was welcomed by the Deputy Mayor, Mr H Levendal. The delegation was informed that all services were completed by December 2005. This constituted phase 1, with 210 subsidies, and phase 2, with 462 subsidies. The contractor had established a presence on the site, while the construction of foundations would begin in early 2010. However, due to the steepness of the area, geotechnical excavation was very expensive. During phase 2, progress was delayed by approximately four months due to the late enrolment of the project by the NHBRC.

The municipality was applying a strategy to collaborate with two contractors. The one contractor would deal with soil preparation, while the other with the top structure. Main contractors subcontracted with local contractors, and employed local people as labourers.

It was a challenge to acquire land that stretched over even terrain, and the province was approached for additional funding. The national Department was requested to reconsider funding to communities located in areas where the topography was steep and uneven.
Deliberations
The delegation sought clarity on the following:
. The site for Community Residential Units (CRUs). . Gap market houses. . Pre-1994 housing stock. . The role of the private sector. . Issues of migration.

The municipality applied for the upgrading of CRUs. Furthermore, while migration patterns into the area were manageable, communities such as Mossel Bay experienced a considerable challenge due to rapid growth. The challenges of the backyard dwellers were addressed, and there were 12 000 beneficiaries on the waiting list.
2.7 Brief presentation by the Chairperson of Community Housing of Great Brak Municipality
Challenges faced by communities in the area were identified as follows:

. Houses built in close proximity to a dam could pose a health hazard to the surrounding community. . Non-payment or very low salaries paid by contractors to workers. . Allegations that white contractors obtained more contracts to build houses compared to black contractors. . Requests were made for assistance in accessing land for churches. . There were few schools, clinics, police stations, and no social amenities for the community.

Ms Dambuza reported that an engagement between the MEC, national Department and the municipality would be arranged to assist with addressing the challenges faced by communities in the area. She further requested the municipality to intervene and to deal with contractors who were exploiting the people. She indicated that a meeting between councillors, contractors, as well as the community would be organised where all the challenges would be discussed.
(a) Site visit to Wolwedans project

The site was serviced in 2005, and top structures were completed in 2009. It was divided into 2 sections, namely the upgrading of informal settlements consisting of 211 units, and the greenfield project. The greenfield project was mainly intended for backyard dwellers and consisted of 466 units. The top structures were enrolled with the NHBRC. All 677 sites were serviced, 20 of the top structures would be roofed by February 2010, and the remaining ones by April 2012.

Houses were electrified, fitted with solar geysers, and were constructed with tiled roofs. When beneficiaries moved into the houses, their shacks would be demolished. During construction, backyard dwellers would be relocated to a temporary relocation area (TRA).

During the delegation's interaction with members of the community, individuals raised concerns regarding the possible threat of the dam located in close proximity to their houses. In particular, the community expressed the threat of the dam to their children's safety. Members of the community requested the delegation's intervention in recommending that the dam should be fenced with a high wall. The community also alleged that the person heading the housing programme in the area was marginalised and not informed about housing initiatives. The community also accused the municipality of being racist in its approach to certain group of people.
Challenges identified The topography of the area, i.e. steep slopes, put additional strain on the available budget. The municipality contributed towards the servicing of the sites.
(b) Site visit to Joe Slovo - Khayelitsha Ward 2

The project started in 1996 with the building of 529 units as a People's Housing Process (PHP) project, through the Utshani Trust Fund. Under PHP management 167 top structures were completed, while 327 top structures were constructed by a contractor. To date, the project had 35 outstanding units. The project ceased operation in 2001 due to an investigation into the Utshani Fund. At the time of the visit, the municipality had advertised for a suitable candidate to take up the position of project manager to manage the process of unblocking the project, as well as other projects such as Highway and Civic Park.

The delegation was further informed by the ward councillor that an application for the rectification of units was approved by the Minister. Five hundred units would be demolished and an assessment was undertaken by Thubelisha. The Deputy Mayor, however, made a contradictory statement by indicating that 120 units would be demolished.

The Deputy Mayor indicated that an in-situ project in Elangeni was stopped in 2008 due to inferior workmanship presented by the initial contractor. The second contractor acknowledged that progress on the project was slow, but committed that by the end of March 2010, work would be complete.

Houses in Khayelitsha were constructed in a format that resembled a garage, which included a toilet. It was further suggested that houses were not fitted with proper infrastructure, and as a result sewerage systems were blocked. It was further arleged that walls were erected on inadequate foundations. In some instances, beneficiaries were expected to complete incomplete units themselves. The following contractors were involved in the projects: New Core (who later changed to Melon), MK, ASLA and Lewis (who accepted funding for nine units which it did not construct).
(c) Site visit: Joe Slovo- Khayelitsha Ward 12

It was reported that the project came to a halt in 1997 when the contractor vanished after being paid to construct 33 PHP houses. The contractor was supposed to construct 527 units. However, the contractor only completed five units, of which some were destroyed by strong winds. The municipality has since appointed a project manager, M vd Harris Construction, from Durban.
The delegation voiced its approval of the size of the units, but expressed concern about the quality of construction, as well as completion of the project.
(d) Site visit Joe Slovo-Zinyoka and Asazani informal settlement

It was reported that the in-situ upgrading was supposed to start in 2006 in accordance with a council resolution. However, the Record of Decision was not approved in time, while EIA was not conducted. The municipality set aside R6.5 million for the construction of access roads. The community was informed that it would be relocated to the identified land.

The community, however, alleged that the municipality was trying to move people away from the well-located land to the periphery. They further argued that the municipality wanted to build flats in that area in its own interest instead. The community alleged that it was not consulted during the process, and that the municipality implemented decisions without its input. Furthermore, the youth did not benefit from development initiatives in the area.

In 2008, the area was affected by a natural disaster, and 13 houses were subsequently destroyed. Members of the community whose houses were destroyed claimed that they did not receive any assistance in this regard. They suggested that Glentana, a place of residence for white people which was also affected by the same disaster, was rebuilt in the same year. Community members claimed that while land was available for private sale, it was not the case for public developments.

It was reported that the ASLA contractor built 2 700 houses in Ward 3 during 2008. However, these units still did not have a water supply, electricity, or toilets. The roofs of these houses leaked when it rained, and the houses were not divided. They were, therefore, not suitable for families because of a lack of privacy.
Observations by the committees

. Community members did not trust the municipality and the delegation recommended that, the matter be addressed. . A task team, comprising of senior officials from the national and provincial government departments, as well as the municipality and the community members, should be formed within two weeks. This team could investigate and address the challenges confronting the project. . The portfolio committee will have to be briefed on the findings of the task team.
Tuesday, 2 February 2010 2.8 Meeting at Beaufort West Municipal Offices
The delegation was welcomed by the Mayor, Ms Jonas.
The following key issues were highlighted for the area:

. The population size was 37 000, with an unemployment rate of 39%. . The housing backlog stood at 3 093 units, while the municipality received an allocation of R3 million for the delivery of houses. . The municipality consisted of 7 wards and 13 councillors. . Subsidies did not cover costs for infrastructure, and funding for bulk infrastructure was inadequate. . A municipal infrastructure grant (MIG) was not allocated to the Karoo. . The delegation observed a combination of good and bad practices. The following good practices were identified:

Good governance, as well as adequate implementation of the Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP) was evident in municipalities such as Laingsburg. . In Paarl significant progress had been made towards employing advanced technology innovations. . Improved quality of the product produced in the recent developments in municipalities such in Mossel Bay, Plettenberg Bay and Merweville in Beaufort West have been improved significantly. . . The majority of municipalities were not committed to the Farm Worker Assistance Programme as required by the National Housing Code. There was no specific programme to manage farm evictions. .
